item.title: A new permanent contest with China over critical minerals will be hard to win
item.description: Australia’s more ambitious critical mineral deal-making is exacting a high price

item.title: Russia’s arrest of Ukrainian scientist brings the chill of geopolitics to the Antarctic
item.description: The charge sheet for “high treason” tells of Moscow’s efforts to undermine the Antarctic Treaty System from within.

item.title: Donald Trump’s tariffs could soon be toast
item.description: A majority of the justices seem skeptical of Mr Trump’s trade war

item.title: Why Palantir’s success will outlast the AI exuberance
item.description: Its valuation looks bonkers. Its business isn’t

item.title: A Victorious Mamdani Will Be Forced Onto the International Stage
item.description: New York’s global profile gives it a powerful role in subnational diplomacy.

item.title: Domestic Challenges Dent Pakistan’s Triumphalism
item.description: As Islamabad draws attention on the global stage, it grapples with economic problems and surging terrorism back home.

item.title: Golden Dome is one of the most ambitious military projects ever
item.description: Even a modest missile shield could upset the balance between nuclear powers

item.title: Sweeping Democratic Wins Serve as a Referendum on Trump 2.0
item.description: State and local election results cast hope for Democratic ambitions in next year’s midterms.

item.title: Democrats Win Big in U.S. State and Local Elections on Anti-Trump Platform
item.description: State and local election results cast hope for Democratic ambitions in next year’s midterms.

item.title: The War Is Over for Israel, but the Accounting Has Yet to Begin
item.description: Will voters settle the score with Bibi—or double down on him?

item.description: Will voters settle the score with Bibi—or double down on him?

item.description: Its growing popularity in America is a concern

item.title: Investors are telling Britain to cheer up a bit
item.description: The country’s economic problems are real, but its assets are doing surprisingly well

item.title: Initial Supreme Court Arguments on Tariffs Case Offer Some Hints
item.description: A number of justices are skeptical of reading too much into the president’s “unlimited” powers.

item.title: Britain Is Having the World’s Most Extreme Immigration Debate
item.description: The British discourse makes even the Trump administration look moderate.

item.title: Britain Is Having the World’s Most Extreme Immigration Debate
item.description: The British discourse makes even the Trump administration look moderate.

item.title: The Cheney Effect
item.description: How Dick Cheney became the accidental architect of Trump’s power.

item.title: The Cheney Effect
item.description: How Dick Cheney became the accidental architect of Trump’s power.

item.title: The Energy Transition Is Achievable in Emerging Markets
item.description: A decade or so ago, a consensus emerged that the energy transition would require massive amounts of capital. But, according to new research into high-emitting sectors in nine major emerging-market economies, power generation will require the least amount of climate finance to shift from fossil fuels to renewables.

item.title: Was the Pacific Palisades blaze a “zombie fire”?
item.description: Fires can linger underground in the Arctic. Might they do the same in California?

item.title: China’s Rare-Earth Own Goal
item.description: Whereas the conventional wisdom holds that the US depends on Chinese rare earths, putting it at a severe geopolitical disadvantage, it is actually China that depends on the US (and others) for higher value-added rare-earth compounds. Any Chinese restrictions on rare-earth exports are thus likely to hurt China most of all.

item.title: Democrats risk drawing the wrong lessons from one good day
item.description: Moderate governors offer a better model than a charming socialist in New York

item.title: Jordan Bardella starts to lay out his plans
item.description: The 30-year-old French populist who is preparing for power

item.title: The Black Atlantic’s Quest for Reparations
item.description: The current geopolitical environment is arguably not conducive to pursuing reparations for slavery and colonialism. But Africa and its diaspora in the Americas, the Caribbean, and Europe continue to make headway, with a focus not only on seeking financial compensation but also on ending racial discrimination.

item.title: France’s Failure in Mali Threatens the World
item.description: Trump’s Nigeria obsession distracts from the real al Qaeda crisis in the Sahel.

item.title: COP30 and COP31 will test middle powers in a climate of opportunity
item.description: Brazil and Australia must prove they can pivot from commodity extraction to clean industrial innovation.

item.title: Israel’s politicians are taking on its lawyers once again
item.description: The arrest of the IDF’s top lawyer will affect Israel’s political future

item.title: How much wealth would be destroyed by an AI stockmarket crash?
item.description: Our visual guide to how a bust the size of the dotcom era could wipe out 8% of Americans’ household wealth

item.title: Tracking American drug-boat strikes off Venezuela’s coast
item.description: Are smugglers or Nicolás Maduro’s regime the target?

item.title: Japan’s Iron Lady
item.description: Japan’s first female prime minister, Takaichi Sanae, presents herself as a leader who can be tougher than the men. This, combined with her hawkish views on immigration and defense, suggests that Takaichi will not use her position to help other women crack the glass ceiling.

item.title: What the Conventional Economic Wisdom Is Missing
item.description: While the economic consensus for the US economy anticipates moderate, steady GDP growth and inflation heading toward 2%, the recent strength of both gold and tech stocks is a signal that investors should not ignore. One way or another, structural economic change is coming.

item.title: Beyond the headlines: the risk of stereotyping women in uniform
item.description: A class action on behalf of female ADF members puts a spotlight on the media portrayal of military women.

item.title: Australia’s mineral diplomacy can connect Africa’s resources to Asia’s demand
item.description: Deeper engagement would help ensure Indo-Pacific partners are not hostage to China’s industrial dominance.

item.title: How to Stop the Genocide in Sudan
item.description: A murdering militia still depends on international legitimacy to survive.

item.title: The Case for Trump’s Second-Term Foreign Policy
item.description: Peace through strength is delivering stability and security.

item.title: The Slow Death of Russian Oil
item.description: Why Ukraine’s campaign against Moscow’s energy sector is working.

item.title: Åland, and the fate of demilitarised islands on Russia’s doorstep
item.description: Deliberately defenceless, this Finnish territory at the heart of the Baltic Sea is still threatened.

item.title: Gerrymandering is now the wind beneath Gavin Newsom’s wings
item.description: His winning gamble to counter Donald Trump’s brazen redistricting may make him the next Democratic nominee for president

item.title: Democrats win big in New York, New Jersey and Virginia
item.description: Donald Trump wasn’t on the ballot. He may as well have been

item.description: Donald Trump wasn’t on the ballot. He may as well have been
